title: Murder of Kirsten Costas
text:
Kirsten Marina Costas (July 23, 1968 – June 23, 1984) was an American high school student who was murdered by her classmate Bernadette Protti in June 1984.
Background.
The daughter of affluent parents Arthur and Berit Costas, Kirsten Costas and her brother Peter grew up in the small suburban town of <a href="Orinda%2C%20California">Orinda, California</a>. Costas attended <a href="Miramonte%20High%20School">Miramonte High School</a> and was a member of the school's varsity swim team and the <a href="cheerleading">cheerleading</a> squad.
Case.
On June 23, 1984, Costas was lured with a phony invitation to a dinner for the Bob-o-Links, a <a href="sorority">sorority</a>-like group at school. According to Protti's later testimony, she had planned to take Costas to the party to befriend her, but Costas became angry when she was told that there was no dinner for the new "Bobbies." The girls quarreled and Costas fled to the home of Alex and Mary Jane Arnold, telling them that her friend had gone "weird." When Costas could not reach her parents by telephone, Alex Arnold drove her home, noticing that the Protti family's <a href="Ford%20Pinto">Pinto</a> was following them. At the Costas home, Arnold, sitting in his car, saw Protti attack Costas. He thought that he was witnessing a fistfight, but in fact Protti had stabbed Costas five times with a <a href="butcher%20knife">butcher knife</a> and fled. The Costases' neighbors called an ambulance, but Kirsten was mortally wounded and died at a nearby hospital.
It took the police almost six months to find Costas' killer. Protti passed a <a href="Polygraph">lie-detector test</a>, but her alibi went unverified. After attempting to confirm Protti's alibi, police suspected that she had lied. Following a conversation with an <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">FBI</a> agent who informed her that her arrest was imminent and that they knew that she had killed Kirsten, Protti wrote her mother a letter in which she made a full confession.
Protti claimed to have found the kitchen knife by chance, and her elder sister, Virginia Varela, testified in court that she kept that knife in her car to cut vegetables. The Costases did not believe Protti's story; they asserted that nobody would use an 18-inch-long (460 mm) butcher knife to slice tomatoes and that Protti, casually dressed that evening, never intended to take Kirsten to a party but had planned to murder her.
Aftermath.
The Costas family left Orinda and moved to <a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> in 1986. 
Protti was sentenced to a maximum of nine years, but was released seven years later in 1992 on parole at the age of 23. Costas' parents vehemently opposed Protti's release.
Adaptations.
American filmmaker <a href="James%20Benning%20%28film%20director%29">James Benning</a> covered the aftermath of the murder in his 1987 documentary "Landscape Suicide".
In 1994, the story was made into a <a href="television%20movie">television movie</a> entitled "<a href="A%20Friend%20to%20Die%20For">A Friend to Die For</a>" (also known as "Death of a Cheerleader"), with <a href="Tori%20Spelling">Tori Spelling</a> as Stacy Lockwood, a character based on Kirsten Costas and <a href="Kellie%20Martin">Kellie Martin</a> as Angela Delvecchio, a character based on Bernadette Protti.
The story was the basis of a 2019 <a href="Lifetime%20%28TV%20network%29">Lifetime</a> <a href="Death%20of%20a%20Cheerleader%20%282019%20film%29">television movie</a> starring Aubrey Peeples as Bridget Moretti and Sarah Dugdale as Kelli Locke, characters based on Protti and Costas, and Martin also had a small role.
Costas' murder was featured in season 5 of "<a href="Deadly%20Women">Deadly Women</a>", season 1, episode 3, of <a href="Investigation%20Discovery">Investigation Discovery</a>'s "The 1980's: The Deadliest Decade", and an episode of "<a href="Killer%20Kids">Killer Kids</a>" titled "Rumors & The To-Do List".
